. Can only be used in the
property.

Returns the minimum value of the inputs.
Selects the output for which the label value matches the input value, or the fallback value if no match is found. The input can be any expression (for example,
). Each label must be unique, and must be either:
Converts the input value to a number, if possible. If the input is
or
, the result is 0. If the input is
, the result is 1. If the input is a string, it is converted to a number as specified by the

of the ECMAScript Language Specification. If multiple values are provided, each one is evaluated in order until the first successful conversion is obtained. If none of the inputs can be converted, the expression is an error.
For two inputs, returns the result of subtracting the second input from the first. For a single input, returns the result of subtracting it from 0.

References variable bound using “let”.
Returns a random value in the specified range (first two input numbers) based on a supplied seed (third input). The seed can be an expression or a constant number or string value.

Creates a color value from red, green, blue components, which must range between 0 and 255, and an alpha component which must range between 0 and 1. If any component is out of range, the expression is an error.
Returns the tangent of the input, interpreted as radians.
Interactive, thoroughly customizable maps for iOS powered by vector tiles and Metal.
Retrieves an item from an array. If the array contains numeric values and the provided index is non-integer, the expression returns an interpolated value between adjacent items.
Returns the base-two logarithm of the input.
Returns a
for use in
entries, and as a section in the
expression.
Produces discrete, stepped results by evaluating a piecewise-constant function defined by pairs of input and output values (“stops”). The
may be any numeric expression (e.g.,
). Stop inputs must be numeric literals in strictly ascending order. Returns the output value of the stop just less than the input, or the first output if the input is less than the first stop.
Returns the smallest integer that is greater than or equal to the input.
Returns
if the first input is greater than or equal to the second,

otherwise. The arguments are required to be either both strings or both numbers; if during evaluation they are not, expression evaluation produces an error. Cases where this constraint is known not to hold at parse time are considered in valid and will produce a parse error. Accepts an optional
argument to control locale-dependent string comparisons.
Returns the product of the inputs.
Returns the distance of a

instance from the center of the map. The distance is measured in pixels divided by the height of the map container. It measures 0 at the center, decreases towards the camera and increase away from the camera. For example, if the height of the map is 1000px, a value of -1 means 1000px away from the center towards the camera, and a value of 1 means a distance of 1000px away from the camera from the center.
may only be used in the
expression for a
layer.
Returns the mathematical constant e.
Returns a
for use in locale-dependent comparison operations. The
and
options default to
. The
argument specifies the IETF language tag of the locale to use. If none is provided, the default locale is used. If the requested locale is not available, the
will use a system-defined fallback locale. Use
to test the results of locale fallback behavior.
Asserts that the input value is a string. If multiple values are provided, each one is evaluated in order until a string is obtained. If none of the inputs are strings, the expression is an error.
Returns the sum of the inputs.
Asserts that the input value is a number. If multiple values are provided, each one is evaluated in order until a number is obtained. If none of the inputs are numbers, the expression is an error.
Returns a four-element array containing the input color’s Hue, Saturation, Luminance and alpha components, in that order.
Returns the input string converted to lowercase. Follows the Unicode Default Case Conversion algorithm and the locale-insensitive case mappings in the Unicode Character Database.
Asserts that the input value is a boolean. If multiple values are provided, each one is evaluated in order until a boolean is obtained. If none of the inputs are booleans, the expression is an error.
Returns the length of an array or string.
Tests for the presence of an property value in the current feature’s properties, or from another object if a second argument is provided.
Converts the input number into a string representation using the providing formatting rules. If set, the
argument specifies the locale to use, as a BCP 47 language tag. If set, the
argument specifies an ISO 4217 code to use for currency-style formatting. If set, the
argument specifies a
to use for unit-style formatting. If set, the
and
arguments specify the minimum and maximum number of fractional digits to include.

may be any numeric expression (e.g.,
). Stop inputs must be numeric literals in strictly ascending order. The output type must be
, or
Retrieves an item from an array.
Returns mathematical constant ln(2).
Returns the progress along a gradient line. Can only be used in the
and
properties.
Creates a color value from hue (range 0-360), saturation and lightness components (range 0-100), and an alpha component (range 0-1). If any component is out of range, the expression is an error.
Rounds the input to the nearest integer. Halfway values are rounded away from zero. For example,
evaluates to -2.
Interpolates using the cubic bezier curve defined by the given control points.
Returns the current zoom level. Note that in style layout and paint properties, [“zoom”] may only appear as the input to a top-level “step” or “interpolate” expression.
Returns
if the evaluated feature is fully contained inside a boundary of the input geometry,
otherwise. The input value can be a valid GeoJSON of type
, or
. Supported features for evaluation:
Returns
if the first input is strictly greater than the second,

otherwise. The arguments are required to be either both strings or both numbers; if during evaluation they are not, expression evaluation produces an error. Cases where this constraint is known not to hold at parse time are considered in valid and will produce a parse error. Accepts an optional
argument to control locale-dependent string comparisons.
Returns
if the input string is expected to render legibly. Returns
if the input string contains sections that cannot be rendered without potential loss of meaning (e.g. Indic scripts that require complex text shaping, or right-to-left scripts if the the
plugin is not in use in Mapbox GL JS).
Returns a string describing the type of the given value.
Returns the mathematical constant pi.
Returns the absolute value of the input.
Returns the feature properties object. Note that in some cases, it may be more efficient to use
directly.
Returns a
string for displaying mixed-format text in the
property. The input may contain a string literal or expression, including an
expression. Strings may be followed by a style override object that supports the following properties:
Returns a requested property of the light configuration based on the supplied options. Currently the only supported option is
which returns the global brightness value of the lights on a scale of 0 to 1, where 0 means total darkness and 1 means full brightness. This expression works only with 3D light, i.e. when
root property is defined.
Returns the arccosine of the input, in radians between −π/2 and π/2.
Returns the current pitch in degrees.
may only be used in the
expression for a
layer.
Returns
if the first input is less than or equal to the second,

otherwise. The arguments are required to be either both strings or both numbers; if during evaluation they are not, expression evaluation produces an error. Cases where this constraint is known not to hold at parse time are considered in valid and will produce a parse error. Accepts an optional
argument to control locale-dependent string comparisons.
Returns the length of the particle velocity vector. Can only be used in the
property.

Converts the input value to a color. If multiple values are provided, each one is evaluated in order until the first successful conversion is obtained. If none of the inputs can be converted, the expression is an error.
Provides a literal array or object value.
Returns the feature’s id, if it has one.
Returns the input string converted to uppercase. Follows the Unicode Default Case Conversion algorithm and the locale-insensitive case mappings in the Unicode Character Database.
Returns the largest integer that is less than or equal to the input.

abstract.text: Returns the arcsine of the input, in radians between −π/2 and π/2.
Creates a color value from hue (range 0-360), saturation and lightness components (range 0-100), and an alpha component of 1. If any component is out of range, the expression is an error.
Creates a color value from red, green, and blue components, which must range between 0 and 255, and an alpha component of 1. If any component is out of range, the expression is an error.
Returns the cosine of the input, interpreted as radians.
Returns the base-ten logarithm of the input.
Returns the kernel density estimation of a pixel in a heatmap layer, which is a relative measure of how many data points are crowded around a particular pixel. Can only be used in the
property.
Converts the input value to a string. If the input is
, the result is
. If the input is a
, the result is
or
. If the input is a number, it is converted to a string as specified by the
of the ECMAScript Language Specification. If the input is a
, it is converted to a string of the form
, where
, and
are numerals ranging from 0 to 255, and
ranges from 0 to 1. If the input is an
expression,
returns the image name. Otherwise, the input is converted to a string in the format specified by the
function of the ECMAScript Language Specification.
Returns the feature’s geometry type:
or
feature types return the singular forms.
An
(expression) defines a formula for computing the value of any layout property, paint property,
or filter within a map style. Expressions allow you to style data with multiple feature
properties at once, apply conditional logic, and manipulate data with mathematical, logical, and
string operators. This allows for sophisticated runtime styling.

Asserts that the input is an array (optionally with a specific item type and length). If, when the input expression is evaluated, it is not of the asserted type, then this assertion will cause the whole expression to be aborted.
Asserts that the input value is an object. If multiple values are provided, each one is evaluated in order until an object is obtained. If none of the inputs are objects, the expression is an error.
Interpolates exponentially between the stops just less than and just
greater than the input. base controls the rate at which the output increases: higher values make the output
increase more towards the high end of the range.
With values close to 1 the output increases linearly.
Converts the input value to a boolean. The result is
when then input is an empty string, 0,
, or
; otherwise it is
Returns the first position at which an item can be found in an array or a substring can be found in a string, or
if the input cannot be found. Accepts an optional index from where to begin the search.
Returns the IETF language tag of the locale being used by the provided
. This can be used to determine the default system locale, or to determine if a requested locale was successfully loaded.
Returns the square root of the input.
Returns the remainder after integer division of the first input by the second.
Returns the result of raising the first input to the power specified by the second.
Returns the result of floating point division of the first input by the second.
Retrieves the configuration value for the given option. Returns null if the requested option is missing.
Returns a
consisting of the concatenation of the inputs. Each input is converted to a string as if by

Returns the raster value of a pixel computed via
. Can only be used in the
property.

Returns an item from an array or a substring from a string from a specified start index, or between a start index and an end index if set. The return value is inclusive of the start index but not of the end index.
Returns a four-element array containing the input color’s red, green, blue, and alpha components, in that order.
Returns the maximum value of the inputs.
Returns the value of a cluster property accumulated so far. Can only be used in the
option of a clustered GeoJSON source.
Logical negation. Returns
if the input is
, and
if the input is
Returns
if the first input is strictly less than the second,

otherwise. The arguments are required to be either both strings or both numbers; if during evaluation they are not, expression evaluation produces an error. Cases where this constraint is known not to hold at parse time are considered in valid and will produce a parse error. Accepts an optional
argument to control locale-dependent string comparisons.
Returns the shortest distance in meters between the evaluated feature and the input geometry. The input value can be a valid GeoJSON of type
, or
. Distance values returned may vary in precision due to loss in precision from encoding geometries, particularly below zoom level 13.
Evaluates each expression in turn until the first valid value is obtained. Invalid values are
and
expressions that are unavailable in the style. If all values are invalid,
returns the first value listed.
Returns the arctangent of the input, in radians between −π/2 and π/2.
Determines whether an item exists in an array or a substring exists in a string. In the specific case when the second and third arguments are string literals, you must wrap at least one of them in a
expression to hint correct interpretation to the
Retrieves a property value from the current feature’s state. Returns

if the requested property is not present on the feature’s state. A feature’s state is not part of the GeoJSON or vector tile data, and must be set programmatically on each feature. Features are identified by their
attribute, which must be an integer or a string that can be cast to an integer. Note that [“feature-state”] can only be used with paint properties that support data-driven styling.
Selects the first output whose corresponding test condition evaluates to true, or the fallback value otherwise.
Returns
if the input values are equal,

otherwise. The comparison is strictly typed: values of different runtime types are always considered unequal. Cases where the types are known to be different at parse time are considered invalid and will produce a parse error. Accepts an optional
argument to control locale-dependent string comparisons.
Returns
if the input values are not equal,

otherwise. The comparison is strictly typed: values of different runtime types are always considered unequal. Cases where the types are known to be different at parse time are considered invalid and will produce a parse error. Accepts an optional
argument to control locale-dependent string comparisons.
Retrieves a property value from the current feature’s properties, or from another object if a second argument is provided. Returns
if the requested property is missing.
Returns the natural logarithm of the input.
Returns the sine of the input, interpreted as radians.
Binds expressions to named variables, which can then be referenced in the result expression using [“var”, “variable_name”].
